choices.A: Decrease the CPU count for VM1.
choices.B: Increase the memory size for VM2.
choices.D: Increase the CPU count for VM4.
choices.C: Decrease the memory size for VM3.

discussion.content: A for me. high ready/wait is CPU related issue., moset wrong VM size. http://www.joshodgers.com/2013/01/12/high-cpu-ready-with-low-cpu-utilization/

I'm going with A. 

The VM is underutilized and its CPU count is keeping the other VMs from properly utilizing the VCPU.

If you increase the memory size for VM2, you can have less than 90% memory utilization.
If you increase the CPU count for VM4, you can have less than 90% CPU utilization.
Is this what it really looks like on the exam or is this a typo? Stuck between B and D equally.

I know most people would say it's D but hear meowt.
The question is about how to fix the high ready/wait times, not the CPU utilization issues.
According to the cited articles having way too many underutilized vCPUs would cause high ready/wait times as those are linked to the physical CPUs (pCPU); thus, decreasing vCPU count from VM1 (very underutilized) would fix alleviate the high ready/wait times for the rest.
The answer is A.

https://learnvmware.online/2018/03/08/performance-troubleshooting-cpu-ready-time/
B is def the correct answer

questions.question_text: The CASB report indicates several unsanctioned SaaS applications are being used in an organization. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause?

discussion.content: Shadow IT, also known as Stealth IT or Client IT, are Information technology (IT) systems built and used within organizations without explicit organizational approval, for example, systems specified and deployed by departments other than the IT department.

questions.question_text:
A company has been migrating a significant number of its on-premises applications to various SaaS providers. The IT department has noticed the following:
1. User account management has become challenging.
2. User account compromises have increased.
3. Accessing various SaaS applications is challenging.
Which of the following should the IT security department implement to BEST resolve the issue? (Choose three.)

discussion.content: I think it should be ABD

choices.F: IPSec tunnel to the SaaS providers

questions.question_text:
A cloud administrator is securing access to a VM using an IaaS cloud platform. The administrator must perform this task using an automated method, allow administrators to perform any method and expose any property of the VM, deny access for everyone else, and allow only read-only access to everyone else.
Given this scenario, which of the following should the administrator use to BEST meet these requirements?

discussion.content:
The answer is JSON D
You write a security policy in json with permit or deny statements
JSON. None of the other option is even covered on this certification
I would really go with "JSON" because it's used in all of the major cloud service providers
I think the answer is JSON
I say JSON. why is JAVA right?
Shouldn't the answer be JSON? Please help to understand how java helps, Thanks

The answer is C Public Federation

https://kb.intermedia.net/article/2538
Multifactor authentication may be a security harden, but C allow this happen

questions.question_text: A company is deploying a new instant messaging app to allow for communications with external vendors. Each entity will host its own version of the application, but users must be able to talk between the companies. Which of the following security techniques would MOST likely be used to allow this to happen?
